timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
               * identified by the pair of timestamp and id. This means that tow unique elements e1, e2 must
          
          
            
               * identified by the pair of timestamp and id. This means that two unique elements e1, e2 must
timeline.author: rezarokni

timeline.bodyText:
Should call out that in the case where there is no unique id, there is loss of information.
Maybe should think about configuration which has to be explicitly overwritten to allow for inserts of two identical elements.
timeline.author: rezarokni

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure I understand. These ids are not visible to the user, rather they are an internal implementation detail.
replies.author: reuvenlax

replies.bodyText: OK, my misunderstanding... where is the id created ? Is it based on the object hash?
replies.author: rezarokni

replies.bodyText: No. A set of available id ranges is stored in an (internal) ValueState, and this class picks a free id from the range.
replies.author: reuvenlax

replies.bodyText: Ah i see that now further down. Nice solution.
replies.author: rezarokni

timeline.bodyText: Would be useful to have a readAndRemoveRange op. When in OnTimer doing process up to this point work, the next step after reading is to clear. So this would save having to make two calls.
timeline.author: rezarokni

replies.bodyText: maybe, but right now I think that would be premature. Users only get charged for bytes transferred, so it's unclear that this would save end users much.
replies.author: reuvenlax

replies.bodyText: I guess I would like to see this in the OrderedListState API, as it would reduce the code the dev needs to write...
replies.author: rezarokni

timeline.bodyText: This should probably extend StructuredCoder instead of CustomCoder, although it may not matter if it's never serialized.  If you leave it as CustomCoder, implement hashCode and equals
timeline.author: dpmills

timeline.bodyText: Could simplify this a little with DelegateCoder
timeline.author: dpmills

timeline.bodyText: For all of these "millis * 1000" calls, use WindmillTimeUtils.harnessToWindmillTimestamp()
timeline.author: dpmills

timeline.bodyText: Put your username or a JIRA issue in the TODOs
timeline.author: dpmills

timeline.bodyText: Use WindmillTimeUtils.windmillToHarnessTimestamp().  Current code is wrong for negative timestamps.
timeline.author: dpmills

timeline.message: Ensure tests run on streaming and fix broken iterable
